entry.title: Re: ATP rule selection in Collective ATP check on COHVPI
entry.content:
How COHV / COHVPI decides which Rule to use is system reads Order Type ‚Üí finds OPJK settings. Checks whether the order is still unreleased or already released. If the corresponding flag is set, it applies the same Checking Rule you‚Äôd get in COR1/COR2. The material‚Äôs Checking Group (OVZ2/OVZ3) and this Checking Rule together define the scope (stocks, receipts, issues) of the ATP check.

When you run a mass material availability check in COHV (Mass Processing: Production Orders) or COHVPI (Mass Processing: Process Orders), the system does not use a new, special rule. It simply picks up the same check logic you‚Äôve defined for individual orders; either for planned orders or for process orders‚Äîbased on your SPRO customizing.

Generally you don‚Äôt use COHV for pure planned orders, but if you do a check in a custom mass process, the logic is the same as CO40. Check in SPRO Production Planning ‚Üí Detailed Scheduling ‚Üí Global Availability Check ‚Üí Maintain Check Mode, Maintain Check Instructions (assign PP event). Only ‚ÄúProduct availability check‚Äù and ‚ÄúCheck against forecast‚Äù functions apply to planned orders.

The below table will give you an idea about Process Orders (Released & Unreleased)

entry.title: Re: Influencing posting price at GR with BAPI_GOODSMVT_CR...
entry.content:
Dear Lakshmipathi, dear Dominik,

thank you for your feedback.
I think the EXBWR parameter works as described in note 3546987, at least when I am checking our movements in the system with MvT 292 or 561.
My intention initially was to influence the price in a GR movement with MvT 101 with  ref to a PO with account assignment F (refurbishment order). 
I think this most probably is covered by question 6 of note 3546987. 

There is a wider Process - which we don' need to discuss here - but at least that you know the root cause of may request.
We are using the refurbishment process with subcontracting, but we do not have split valuated materials, which somehow is a prerequisite for this.
In this process there are to goods receipt postings with MvT 101.
One done by the user with transaction MIGO with reference to subcontracting PO, which includes MvT 101 (GR) and MvT 543 (consumtion of subcontracting stock). Since the PO has an account assignment F with reference  to the refurbishment order, it is consumed and the stock level is not correct.
Therefore a second automatic  GR posting is triggered by BADI_DIAD_GOODMVT_1, which adjusts the stock level.

Our problem is now, that since we don't use split valuation for materials, the amount of this two GR postings are added, that partly the refurbished materials are more expensive as new identical materials would be. First GR is valuated with the PO price (refurbishment costs) and the second one with the moving average price of the refurbished material. 

Therefor my intention was to post the second GR like free of charge in oder that the moving average price is not updated with it, but unfortunately this doesn't work.
I think I will try to raise this in a customer influence request, since split valuation is not very common. At least for small and mid sized companies.

Br Heinz

entry.title: Display of the Number of Goals per User in People Analytics Story Reporting
entry.content:
A typical requirement in talent management reporting is to show the number of employees according to the number of goals, i.e. performance goals or development goals. Such a chart could help to identify employees which have not yet defined any goals, or also employees which have too many or too less goals. In this blogpost alternative approaches are presented to realize such a reporting requirement in People Analytics Story Reporting.

Introduction

An important HR requirement in talent management is to identify employees which have not yet defined any goals, or also employees which have too many or too less goals. See left side in Figure 1 which shows

  • Total number of considered employees
  • Total number of Objective plans which is the number of combinations of employees and objective plans (e.g. if one employee has goals in 3 of the selected objective plans, then the number ‚Äú3‚Äù is considered; if an employee has goals in a single objective plan or also in none of the selected objective plans, then the number ‚Äú1‚Äù is considered)
  • Total number of Goals (e.g. if an employee has 3 goals in ‚Äòobjective plan A‚Äô and 5 goals in ‚Äòobjective plan B‚Äô, then the number ‚Äú8‚Äù is considered)
  • Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan, i.e. which is just the ‚ÄúTotal number of Goals‚Äù divided by the ‚ÄúTotal Number of  Objective Plans‚Äù

The chart in Figure 1 shows the ‚ÄúTotal Number of Objective Plans‚Äú according to the number of goals. You can see that there are 1229 employees which don‚Äôt have any goals in one of the selected objective plans, 28 employees with a single goal in the selected objective plans, 11 employees with 2 goals and so on.

 Figure 1   'Histogram' (more precise, 'chart of type "Bar/Column") to show the number of employees per number of goals

Solution Approach

In the following the different steps are explained how to create a query and the respective story to derive the chart as it is shown in Figure 1.

1. Query creation

Create the query as shown in Figure 2. Note that:

  • The object ‚ÄúPrimary Objective Fields‚Äù from ‚ÄúAll Templates‚Äù in schema ‚ÄúObjective Management‚Äù is used. This was chosen to allow the possibility to select one or multiple bonus plans as indicated in Figure 1 on the right.
  • The anchor of the query is ‚ÄúBasic User Information‚Äù from schema ‚ÄúUser‚Äù. It is also possible to create the query the other way round. However, only when having "Basic User Information" as anchor it is possible to derive also the employees without any goal plans and goals.

Select at least fields like employee name, user ID, objective plan ID, objective plan name and goal. You might add also filters e.g. to consider only goal plans in status ‚Äúcompleted‚Äù, ‚Äúon track‚Äù but to ignore goal plans in status ‚ÄúCancelled‚Äù or ‚ÄúPostponed‚Äù.

Figure 2   Query based on ‚ÄúAll Templates‚Äù within schema ‚ÄúObjective Management‚Äù

2. Story measure calculations

Create the following 4 story calculations as indicated in Figure 3, 4, 5 and 6.

To illustrate the necessity to calculate the ‚ÄúTotal Number of Objective Plans‚Äù let‚Äôs consider the following example: Assume there are 100 employees for ‚Äúgoal plan 2023‚Äù and 120 employees for ‚Äúgoal plan 2024‚Äù. Further assume you run the report for both bonus plans. Then the number of employees is 120 (under the assumption that the 100 employees of ‚Äúgoal plan 2023‚Äù are among the employees relevant for ‚Äúgoal plan 2024‚Äù). This is derived with the calculated measure ‚ÄúEmployees‚Äù as shown in Figure 3. However, more important for our report is the combination of employees and goal plans which is 220 (=100 + 120). This is derived with the calculated measure ‚ÄúTotal Number of Objective Plans‚Äù as shown in Figure 4.

Figure 3   Story calculation of type ‚ÄòAggregation‚Äô to derive the number of employees

Figure 4   Story calculation of type ‚ÄòAggregation‚Äô to derive the total number of objective plans

The next calculation is the overall number of ‚Äúgoals‚Äù. Let‚Äôs stick at the example from above; let‚Äôs assume that the 100 employees maintained in objective plan ‚Äúgoal plan 2023‚Äù overall 400 goals and that the 120 employees maintained in objective plan ‚Äúgoal plan 2024‚Äù overall 590 goals. Here, it could be possible that one goal as e.g. ‚ÄúImprove my leadership skills‚Äù is for some of the employees part of ‚Äúgoal plan 2023‚Äù as well as part of ‚Äúgoal plan 2024‚Äù. Nevertheless, the combination of employees and goal plans is 990 (=400 + 590). This is derived with the calculated measure ‚ÄúTotal Number of Goals‚Äù as shown in Figure 5. To derive the ‚ÄúNumber of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan‚Äù it is now just required to divide the ‚ÄúTotal number of goals‚Äù and ‚ÄúTotal Number of Objective Plans‚Äù. For the example here, this would be an average number of 4,5 goals (=990 / 220).

Figure 5   Story calculation of type ‚ÄòAggregation‚Äô to derive the number of goals

Figure 6   Story calculation of type ‚ÄòCalculated Measure‚Äô to derive the quotient between ‚ÄúNumber of Goals‚Äù and ‚ÄúTotal Number  of Objective Plans‚Äù

 3. Story Dimension Calculation

The final calculation step is transforming the ‚ÄúNumber of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan‚Äù into a dimension. It is important to consider the ‚ÄúDimension Context‚Äù: Our use case is to show the Number of Goals per Employee and Objective Plan. Therefore, the dimension context is the employee (i.e. the field ‚ÄòUser ID‚Äô) and the goal plan (i.e. ‚Äòobjective plan ID‚Äô). Here, the bit ‚Äòtricky‚Äô part is to find meaningful ‚Äògoal ranges‚Äô (i.e. ‚ÄòMember Name‚Äô) so that the visual representation results in a chart that basically resembles a Gaussian distribution (see Figure 7). Furthermore, it is recommended to provide a counter as prefix to the ‚ÄôMember Name‚Äô (i.e. (1), (2), (3), ‚Ä¶.), so that the sorting works properly (if this ‚Äòprefix would be missing, in the sample provided here the sorting would be ‚Äú1 Goal‚Äù, ‚Äú13-15 Goals‚Äù, ‚Äú16 and More Goals‚Äù, ‚Äú2 Goals‚Äù, ‚Äú3 Goals‚Äù, ‚Ä¶.).

Figure 7   Story calculation of type ‚ÄòMeasure-Based Dimension‚Äô to convert the ‚ÄúNumber of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan‚Äù

4. Chart Creation

Finally, it is possible to create a visual presentation of the previously calculated figures. Figure 8 shows a ‚ÄúBar/Column‚Äù chart with the measure ‚ÄúTotal Number of Objective Plans‚Äù and dimension ‚ÄúGoal Ranges‚Äù.

Figure 8   Bar chart with measure ‚ÄòTotal Number of Objective Plans‚Äô and dimension ‚ÄòGoal Ranges‚Äô

5. Further remarks:

  • Of course, the presented approach works not only for goals/objective data but also for (1) any similar (e.g. performance form data) or (2) also slightly different use cases (e.g. number of particular benefits rolled out/claimed per employee).
  • Instead of manual definition of ‚ÄúMember Names‚Äù as shown in Figure 7 you could also tick ‚ÄúUse measure values as dimension members‚Äù. However, in addition to the shortcomings described above (1. no Gaussian distribution; 2. confusing sorting), ‚Äòmembers‚Äô without any ‚ÄòGoals per Employee/Objective Plan‚Äô would not show up in the Bar Chart.
  • It is also possible to use a chart of type ‚ÄúHistogram‚Äù. Use ‚ÄúTotal Number of Goals‚Äù as ‚ÄòMeasure‚Äô and ‚ÄúUser ID‚Äù and "Objective Plan ID" as ‚ÄòAggregation Dimension‚Äô. Then, you have to adjust the ‚ÄòChart Properties‚Äô. It is not recommended to switch off ‚ÄòAutomatically Set Range of Values‚Äô: With this option you would probably generate odd ranges. However, for the use case of goals it is recommended to use fixed ranges as e.g. ‚Äú14‚Äù as ‚Äú‚ÄôNumber of bins‚Äô and ‚Äú1‚Äù and ‚Äú15‚Äù as ‚ÄòMinimum‚Äô/‚ÄôMaximum‚Äô (important: choose 'Number of Bins' plus "1" for the 'Maximum'; only then each range covers the range of "1.00"). As shown in Figure 9 this approach works also fine (compare numbers from Figure 1 with numbers of Figure 9). 
    Advantage: This approach is faster to implement; only "Total Number of Goals" (see Figure 5) needs to be created
    Disadvantage: (a) The case of employees without any goal (see 1st column of 1229 employees/goal plans without any goal defined) is missing and (b) Less flexibility regarding the definition of 'Goal Ranges' (in particular to define something like "More than 16 goals)"
    Therefore, the approach which is previously described is more recommended.

 Figure 9   Chart of type "Histogram" to show the number of goals per employee/objective plan
